docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush again called on the Senate to follow the House and pass a bill allowing small businesses to band together across state lines to buy insurance at the type of discounts that large corporations get. In remarks before the American Hospital Association, Mr. Bush also asked the Senate to limit lawsuits against health care providers, a move that he said could help reduce costs. White House and Senate officials said senators could address health care legislation within the week, but many Democrats oppose the initiatives. ''Both are just a giveaway to special interests,'' said Jim Manley, a spokesman for Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader. A call to the office of Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, was not returned. JIM RUTENBERG (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Forge Your Way Through the Medicare Drug Maze'' (Personal Health, April 25): After providing a most useful summary of the current status of enrollment in the new Medicare Part D drug insurance, Jane Brody concludes with practical, step-by-step advice on determining which of the plans (in my case, 42 of them) is most advantageous. She suggests calling the companies and asking about co-payments and restrictions. Call 42 drug companies? No, thanks! Aside from communication problems (I use hearing aids), I have much better use for my time -- especially given a constant awareness of how little time remains when one has passed the age of 90! And there is so much to do, day after day -- including a close reading of my New York Times! Ernest Erber Red Hook, N.Y.
docs.abstract: Ernest Erber letter on Jane Brody April 25 Personal Health column about Medicare drug plan says that following her suggestions would take too much time

docs.lead_paragraph: YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with ''Your Money,'' a free weekly newsletter that can be found at nytimes.com/yourmoney CHINA RISES -- China is the scene of an extraordinary economic, social and political transformation. But it is also struggling with an enormous population, a strained environment and unequal distribution of wealth and opportunity. A four-part series is at nytimes.com/specials/chinarises/intro. SMALL BUSINESS -- Wal-Mart, through its Sam's Club division, can be a most unlikely ally of the mom-and-pop store. An audio slide show can be found at nytimes.com/business/smallbusiness. Business Briefing For article: nytimes.com/business. THE UNITEDHEALTH GROUP,under fire for the timing of lucrative options grants to executives, said that it had discontinued equity-based awards to its two most senior managers and that it would cease other perks like paying for personal use of corporate aircraft. (REUTERS) HUMANA, the health insurance company, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 22 percent, partly because of costs from the start-up of its Medicare prescription drug plans. The company said its Medicare revenue rose by $1.25 billion, or 127 percent, from the year-earlier period. (AP) TYSON FOODS, the meat processor, lost $127 million in its second quarter, citing oversupply in its beef, chicken and pork operations and charges for plant closings. The loss amounted to 37 cents a share for the quarter compared with a profit of $76 million, or 21 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue slipped to $6.25 billion from $6.36 billion. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: SMALL-BUSINESS owners know they cannot do everything. Their first priority has to be the product line. Nevertheless, all the ancillary functions that are part of running a company -- order-taking and shipping, payroll, employee benefits, customer service, Web site maintenance, publicity -- must get done somehow. For many businesses, the answer is to farm out the work to specialized contractors, whether payroll-services companies or Web designers. Yet outsourcing that work can bring its own set of problems. It means giving away control to a third party who may not do things the way a business owner wants. If the vendor has bigger clients, a small business may be sent to the back burner. And outsourcing doesn't necessarily save money.
docs.abstract: Article on question of whether small business owners should outsource some work and services to contractors; drawing (special section, Small Business) (M)
